title: How can a man fight back against unbelievably unfair divorce judgments that will keep him in the poorhouse unti lhis death?
question: After the kids left the nest the wife took to gambling, racking up debt on his credit cards. While he was at work she would sign his name on new card offers and rack up more gambling debt. She did not ever work. It came to around $100,000.
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce appeals,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Social security,Family law,Appeals
answers: You asked if there were any remedies available to you that wouldn't cost a lot of dollars. The answer, in short is probably not. When you have a judgment, there are limited remedies available. There is a motion to reconsider, motion to set aside and most importantly appeal. All of these options have deadlines associated with them and you could loose all recourse forever if you do not move quickly. I recommend you find a well respected appellate attorney in your area who has experience with family law for a consultation. As part of your consideration, you will want to think about whether, the judgment, as unfair as it is, would be something you could live with when facing the costs and uncertainty of an appeal. Good luck!
If he is unhappy with the decision, his recourse is to file an appeal. He should meet with a local attorney, ASAP to see if he still as time to file one.

This sounds really unfair from your perspective. Know that there are other perspectives which may view the decision as fair. Nevertheless, it sounds like the decision was already made by the court. Now you need to figure out how to live with it.

Decide you are going to learn whatever you can from this. Good or bad. Be alert for insights. Let go of your anger. Don't be a victim or you will stay stuck in negativeland. Make a list of everything that is good in your life right now. List what you do have. Focus on the positive. Seek out counseling to help you rid yourself of anger and depression.

Not all legal decisions are fair. I know; I have lived this. The most important thing you can do is decide not to be bitter, angry, a victim, revengeful. It only hurts you. Do what you can do. Take each day as it comes. Change what you can, let go of the rest.

This is not intended to be "woo-woo" New Age advice. It is self-preservation. Take care of yourself. Don't spend the rest of your life chained to this story. Find a new, positive story for yourself. Let this be a catalyst for change. You are not too old to have a new beginning that is good. Look for it, find it. Enjoy the rest of your life with it.

Best wishes and hugs,
Meredith :-)
